Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial on Labor Epidural Conversion Failure for Caesarean Delivery

Trial_Design.evidence: The study did not employ randomisation or blinding, as it was a retrospective analysis.

Participants.evidence: including pregnant patients from November 2009 to September 2014 who required CD with a pre-existing labor epidural.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the incidence and risk factors of labor epidural conversion failure requiring general anesthesia for Caesarean delivery (CD).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the rate of epidural conversion failure, defined as the need for general anesthesia prior to or during CD.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: The study did not employ randomisation or blinding, as it was a retrospective analysis.

Blinding.evidence: The study did not employ randomisation or blinding, as it was a retrospective analysis.

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 673 patients were included

Result_Outcome.evidence: Significant risk factors included younger maternal age (OR 0.94, 95% CI 0.90 to 0.97, P = 0.0002), and the use of intravenous fentanyl (OR 0.19, 95% CI 0.10 to 0.35, P < 0.0001) or midazolam (OR 0.26, 95% CI 0.12 to 0.57, P = 0.0008) during CD.

Trial_Registration.evidence: The study was not registered as a trial
